S-Shaped Growth: Modeling the Natural System of a Flowered Area

Flower Model - Intrinsic Growth vs. Actual Growth Rate

This model explores one of the six types of dynamic patterns: S-Shaped Growth graphings. S-Shaped graphs are crucial for describing patterns in natural systems. This project simulates the spread of flowers across a 1,000-acre landscape.

There are two stocks in the model above: â€œFlowered Areaâ€ and â€œEmpty Area.â€ The initial value for the â€œFlowered Areaâ€ is 10 acres; the â€œEmpty Areaâ€ is 990 acres. With 10 acres purely of flowers, there will be minimal limitations hindering their spread - the seeds will have open space to grow in all directions. The variable â€œDecay Rateâ€ is set to 20% per year, and is the product of the â€œFlowered Areaâ€ and rate of decay. The growth of the â€œFlowered Areaâ€ is dictated by the â€œGrowth Rateâ€ variable (a product of the Growth Rate and Flowered Area).

If the model above only took the stated variables for simulation, the flowered area would expand by 80% per year. With no resource limitations, the model would assume an Intrinsic Growth Rate. To develop a more realistic model of the natural spread of flowers, an â€œActual Growth Rateâ€ variable will be introduced to the simulation. The â€œActual Growth Rateâ€ will be less than the Intrinsic Growth Rate of our first scenario - as the flowers spread across the landscape, the amount of â€œEmpty Areaâ€ available will decrease and the flowersâ€™ possibility to germinate will be increasingly harder.

The graph above illustrates a remarkably quick spread of the â€œFlowered Areaâ€ within the first 10 years, but a dynamic equilibrium at 800 acres - not the full 1,000 acres available in the landscape. The â€œFlowered Areaâ€ starts with 10 acres, and within 6 years is covering 50 times its original breadth at a whopping 500 acres. This 6th year on the graph indicates the highest rate of growth in the â€œFlowered Areaâ€ as the growth exceeds the decay by the biggest margin. After this, the increasing trends starts to stabilize and eventually tapers off - an inverse of the first 6 years with a new decline in growth and increase in decay. Dynamic Equilibrium is met around the 12th year, 4/5th of the landscape completely covered in flowers. The flowers will never cover the entire landscape, because the â€œDecay Rateâ€ is fixed at 20% throughout the simulation.

Introducing a Disturbance - The Implications of Equilibrium

This model allows for a disturbance to remove 20% of the flowers. The â€œDisturbanceâ€ Converter is linked with a newly added â€œDisturbance Flowâ€ that will enact on the 15th year of the simulation. The â€œTotal Areaâ€ internal variable has been changed to a Stock in the model. The model was set for a duration of 20 years to indicate if equilibrium would be reached, but the added â€œDisturbanceâ€ only reduced the â€œFlowered Areaâ€ for the year it was enacted. The flowers gradually reached back to their apex of 800 acres 5 years after the â€œDisturbanceâ€ occurred.
